content: The Act titled "Identity Theft Protection Act of 2001" restricts the use of Social Security Account Numbers. The "Identity Theft Protection Act of 2001" restricts the use of Social Security Account Numbers by repealing certain provisions and implementing new rules for randomly generated numbers. The "Identity Theft Protection Act of 2001" restricts the disclosure of Social Security account numbers to individuals only, prohibiting their sharing with government agencies or other entities. Additionally, the act allows for the use of the SSN as an identifying number for specific purposes outlined in the Internal Revenue Code. The "Identity Theft Protection Act of 2001" limits the sharing of Social Security numbers to individuals only and allows their use for specific purposes in the Internal Revenue Code. Amendments are made to section 6109 of the Internal Revenue Code regarding the use of SSNs, with effective dates to be determined by the Commissioner of Social Security. The amendments made by subsections (a), (b), and (c) of the "Identity Theft Protection Act of 2001" will take effect 5 years after the enactment of the Act. The Commissioner of Social Security will reissue new social security account numbers to individuals within this timeframe. Upon enactment of the "Identity Theft Protection Act of 2001," individuals with social security account numbers issued before the specified date will receive new numbers. The old numbers will be void and subject to certain requirements.
